Generate a Bar Chart Using ggplot2 or Highcharter

BarChart.Rd

This function creates a bar chart using either the ggplot2 or highcharter package. It allows customization of various chart attributes such as labels, colors, position type, and text display.

Usage

BarChart(
  df,
  x_col,
  y_col,
  color_col,
  bar_type = c("stack", "group"),
  x_label = "",
  y_label = "",
  chart_title = NULL,
  show_bar_text = FALSE,
  chart_flip = FALSE,
  plot_engine = c("ggplot2", "highcharter"),
  axis_text_size = 12,
  num_abv_grph_size = 4,
  txt_space_abv_grh = 0.005
)

Arguments

df

A data frame containing the data to be plotted.

x_col

A string specifying the column name to be used for the x-axis.

y_col

A string specifying the column name to be used for the y-axis.

color_col

A string specifying the column name to be used for color grouping.

bar_type

A character string specifying how bars should be positioned. Options are "stack" for stacked bars or "group" for grouped bars.

x_label

A string specifying the label for the x-axis.

y_label

A string specifying the label for the y-axis.

chart_title

A string specifying the title of the chart.

show_bar_text

A logical indicating whether to display text labels on bars.

chart_flip

A logical indicating whether to flip the chart (horizontal bars).

plot_engine

A character string specifying which plotting library to use. Options are "ggplot2" (default) or "highcharter".

axis_text_size

A numeric value specifying the text size for axis labels.

num_abv_grph_size

A numeric value specifying the font size of numeric labels above bars.

txt_space_abv_grh

A numeric value specifying the space above the bars for text labels.

Value

A ggplot or highcharter object representing the bar chart.

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
df <- data.frame(
  category = c("A", "B", "C"),
  value = c(10, 20, 15),
  group = c("X", "Y", "X")
)
BarChart(df, x_col = "category", y_col = "value", color_col = "group",
         position_type = "stack", plot_engine = "ggplot2")
} # }
